Two-part structure, consisting of an antecendent (HC or IAC) and a consequent (concluded by PAC)

Two-part structure, consisting of a presentation (no cadence) and a continuation (concluded by a half or full cadence). The presentation in turn is made up  of two (less frequently one or three) basic ideas.

Antecedent + cadential progression

Following a first thematic phrase, there is a restatement of bi, closing with ci on PAC
smallest formal unit of a theme (typically 2 bars in length)
basic idea is enlarged; it consists of two distinct parts, featuring prolongational harmony. It does not cadence.
smallest motivic (formal) unit of a theme; is in contrast to a preceding basic idea.
at the end of a theme/phrase

Second part of sentence, leads to cadence at the end (HC, IAC or PAC), unless the theme is of the dissolving type
